metadata.titleEn: Geochemical data of Early Paleozoic high Ba-Sr intrusions in the North Qinling block, China
metadata.description: The data are U-Pb dating data, mineral trace geochemical data, whole rock major trace geochemical data and isotopic geochemical data of high Ba SR intrusives. Samples were collected from quartz diorite and diorite of high Ba SR intrusion in North Qinling block. The U-Pb isotopic data of zircon were obtained by laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. The major and trace geochemical data of the whole rock were obtained by X-ray fluorescence spectrometry and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. The whole rock isotopic geochemical data were obtained by multi receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. The obtained data can reveal the petrogenesis of different high Ba SR intrusions and limit the formation time of corresponding tectonic settings.
metadata.instructions: All data are stored in Excel file. The name of the file "UPB" represents radioisotope data. The name of the file "wrmajtra" represents the major and trace geochemical data of the whole rock. The name of the file "WR isotopic" represents the whole rock SR – nd – Hf isotopic data. The file name "zircon tra" represents zircon trace element data.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific attributes of high Ba-Sr intrusions measured using geochemical methods?
Feature Specification.Answer: radiogenic isotope U-Pb dating, mineral trace geochemical data, whole-rock major and trace geochemical data, whole-rock isotopic geochemical data

Quantification.Question: How many types of geochemical data are included in a dataset focused on early Paleozoic high Ba-Sr intrusions in the North Qinling Block?

Interpretation.Question: What geological processes might be inferred from the geochemical data patterns observed in high Ba-Sr intrusive rocks, and how might these insights inform our understanding of the tectonic history of the North Qinling terrane?
Interpretation.Answer: The geochemical data from high Ba-Sr intrusive rocks, including isotopic data such as U-Pb zircon dating and whole-rock geochemistry, can provide insights into the origin of these rocks and their tectonic setting. By analyzing the isotopic and geochemical signatures, researchers can infer the processes that led to the formation of the intrusive bodies, such as magma source characteristics and differentiation processes. This, in turn, can help to constrain the timing and nature of tectonic events that influenced the formation of the North Qinling terrane.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the choice of analytical techniques such as laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry and X-ray fluorescence spectrometry in the collection of geochemical data from high Ba-Sr intrusive rocks in the North Qinling terrane?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The choice of analytical techniques like laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) and X-ray fluorescence spectrometry (XRF) is driven by the need for precise isotopic dating and detailed geochemical analysis of mineral and whole-rock samples. LA-ICP-MS is used for zircon U-Pb isotope analysis due to its ability to provide high-resolution age data essential for understanding the formation and tectonic history of high Ba-Sr intrusive rocks. XRF and ICP-MS are chosen for whole-rock major and trace element geochemistry to comprehensively characterize the composition and genesis of these rocks. These methods are selected for their accuracy, sensitivity, and ability to analyze a wide range of elements critical for geochemical characterization.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for zircon U-Pb isotopic analysis on the precision and accuracy of geochronological data in studying Early Paleozoic high Ba-Sr intrusions in the North Qinling Block?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry for zircon U-Pb isotopic analysis can lead to high precision and accuracy in geochronological data, which is crucial for determining the formation timing and tectonic settings of high Ba-Sr intrusions. This method allows for detailed age dating and helps in understanding the petrogenesis of the rocks, providing insights into the geological history and processes that formed these intrusions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose behind collecting and analyzing geochemical data for high Ba-Sr intrusive bodies in the early Paleozoic era of the North Qinling block?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose of collecting and analyzing geochemical data for high Ba-Sr intrusive bodies in the early Paleozoic era of the North Qinling block is to reveal the genesis of different high Ba-Sr intrusive rocks and to define the timing of formation within their respective tectonic settings. This is achieved through U-Pb isotopic dating, mineral trace geochemistry, whole-rock major and trace geochemistry, and isotopic geochemistry using various analytical techniques.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumental methodologies are employed to accurately determine zircon U-Pb isotopic ages in the context of geochemical data collection for early Paleozoic high Ba-Sr intrusions in the North Qinling terrane?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Zircon U-Pb isotopic ages are determined using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) to analyze zircon samples from high Ba-Sr intrusions.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the precise analysis of zircon U-Pb isotopes for determining the age of high Ba-Sr intrusive rocks?
Enablement.Answer: The precise analysis of zircon U-Pb isotopes for age determination is enabled by the use of laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS).
